In behaviorism, positive reinforcement is not the same as "reward," and negative reinforcement is not "punishment." Reinforcement is anything that increases the likelihood of a behavior occurring. Punishment is anything that decreases the likelihood of the behavior occurring. Positive means something is added; negative means something is removed. So you can have negative/positive reinforcements and negative/positive punishments depending on if something was added or removed and whether or not it increases or decreases the likelihood of a bx occurring.

A small correction and obviously 12 years late, but negative reinforcement is NOT punishment.  Negative reinforcement is the removal of an aversive condition to serve as reward, such that it increases (or REINFORCES) the behavior.  Punishment, be it positive (i.e. introducing an aversive condition) or negative (i.e. removing a desirable condition), seeks to decrease the frequency of behavior.

I wish all university lecturers could communicate ideas in such an incredibly clear and engaging way. He’s a natural teacher and one gets the sense that he really wants his young students to be as fascinated by the complexity and awesomeness of the natural world as well as how weird we are as a species. He is even very clear about what is going to be important for their approach to studying for the exams, what is going to be most important, what chapters in the “textbooks” they need to read and whether to read them before or after listening to the lecture as well as providing copies of individual published studies that are relevant to the topic and suggesting which ones are worthy of reading in entirety and those where the abstract is sufficient as well as what level of detail they need to memorise for the purposes of the exams. It saves students so much time trying to figure out what’s important for the purposes of the examinations versus all the fascinating information he communicates in his books and lectures.  He doesn’t stop talking, but he never gets boring and keeps the logical thread of the topic developing in the right order. He is such a wonderful teacher and communicator, it’s a joy to watch and I learn so much in such a short time.

Summary :   1. Evolution of psychology and ethology  The history and evolution of psychology and ethology includes the dominance of behaviorism in American psychology, the importance of studying animal behavior in natural environments, and the benefits of enriched environments for brain development. Animal behavior has become a significant aspect of ethology, as understanding such behavior provides important insights into the adaptive mechanisms and survival strategies.  2. Fixed action patterns in animals and humans  Fixed action patterns, observed in both animals and humans, are innate behaviors triggered by specific environmental stimuli. The concept has been studied by ethologists and evolutionary biologists for its adaptive value and role in passing on genes over generations. Learning and experience can enhance these behaviors, but their hardwired nature remains a key aspect of these patterns.  3. Studying animal behavior and communication  Animal behavior studies include the exploration of communication methods and sensory modalities. Researchers use experimental techniques to study fixed action patterns in animals, such as bee dance languages and the use of robotic animals to elicit responses from real animals. Understanding how animals perceive and interact with their environment has led to groundbreaking discoveries in various fields.  4. Importance of touch and cuteness in development  Touch is a critical aspect of healthy infant development, and positive reinforcement goes beyond food to include physical and emotional comfort. The phenomenon of cuteness in baby animals has been studied and incorporated into popular culture, as these features evoke nurturing and protective instincts in adults.  5. Neuro ethology and behavioral understanding  Neuro-ethology examines animal behavior by understanding the neural and endocrine processes underlying it. This approach has led to significant progress in various fields, including bird song neurobiology, the female hamster lordosis reflex, and brain chemistry studies of baboons in their native habitats. Ethologists have also discovered traditional and unexpected types of learning in animals.  6. Learning and adaptation in animal behavior  Animals are capable of learning and adapting through trial and error, classical conditioning, and tool-making. Experience and hands-on practice are vital to mastering skills like parenting, hunting, and tool-making, with larger social groups facilitating earlier development of these abilities.  7. Unconventional learning and awareness in animals  Unconventional learning types in animals, such as imprinting and prepared learning, challenge the traditional reinforcement theory. For example, bees exhibit a preference for smell associations over shape associations when learning food sources, and humans and monkeys quickly associate spiders and snakes with unpleasant stimuli.  8. Animal cognition, self-awareness, and understanding  Animal cognition studies include understanding self-awareness, as demonstrated through the mirror test and other experiments. Animals like chimpanzees, non-human primates, and birds possess cognitive abilities such as recognizing individual voices, understanding numbers, and having a theory of mind. They can also distinguish between intentional and unintentional behaviors and plan for the future. These findings fall within the realm of cognitive ethology, which studies animals' cognitive abilities. No one is claiming that some behaviour isn't learned, but you can't reduce all behaviour to stimulus and response. You can't reduce all mental states to behaviour either, but behaviourism doesn't care about mental states. Tolman (a behaviourist) showed that we can in fact make inferences about mental states, The Brelands (Students of Skinner), in their article "The misbehaviour of organisms", showed us limitations to conditioning. It's not about disproving, it's about behaviourism being too limited to explain the full range of human experience and behaviour. That's why we got the cognitive revolution, that's why behaviourism has gone from dominating psychology around 1950 to being a niche, mostly just applied to autistics and drug addicts today. The true father of Ethology is Eugene Marais, South African writer who had begun informally published his 'in the field' research observing white termites and baboons. Flemish playwright 'Count' Maeterlinck was able to understand Afrikaans which is very similar to Flemish and stole the work, publishing it without attribution as his original thoughts. By the early 1920's Marais was publishing in a series for the South African magazine 'Huisgenoot' and by the late 1920's he had published his seminal book on the behaviour of termites 'The Soul of the White Ant'. He had experiences which were unparalleled in Europe, living in the remote Waterberg region and observing nature first hand. He was the first man to live among baboons, which Professor Sapolsky may find interesting. Very sad that his life's work was stolen and his life ended in suicide. He was the true pioneer of ethology. I defy anyone to read 'The Soul of the White Ant/Termite' and disagree. Fixed Action Patterns are something my Grandmother interpreted in chickens without knowing it. She understood the difference between their squawks and peeps and that they had a specific sound for 'alarming things from above' and so on. I suspect country folk naturally learnt these Fixed Pattern Action languages but simply lacked the and training to write them in what academics consider a 'scientific' way.

Ethology is about interviewing an animal in it's own language.  Nicolaas Tinbergen, Conrad Lorenz, Karl von Frisch (1973 Nobel laurets in Physiology/Medicine)  Contrasts with behaviorism - which is about extreme environmentalism - you can control everything about an animal's behaviour through positive and negative reinforcements.  The questions that ethology asks - 1. What is the fixed action pattern?  2. How can it be improve upon? (ie what are the contexts in which the animal learns to do it better?) 3. What are the evolutionary advantages of having that fixed action pattern? 4. What stimuli from the outside environment triggers the pattern? 5. What happens inside the animal's nervous system between a stimulus triggering a behaviour and that behaviour actually occurring? 6. What does learning have to do with all this?

Conceptual correction ([for] doc has [heard stories of, but] not studied behaviorism): > + & - Reinforcers are both "rewards" in the sense of "motivators", differing in wether "adding" or "removing" stimuli (that are appetitive to a behavior, or to overall organism when the a specific behaving is a clear circumstantial prefference). > The "punishments" in the sense of "deterrence", is a third thingy (ambient-subject presenting subject-object any of annoying or discounforting stimulli), and can also be understood as - or + in the same sense (relative to stimulus presentation). > All these definitions are consequentialist (you can notice what "has been" [i.e. a reinforcer], but only infer what "will be").  It's quite common to people confude "negative reinforcement" and "(positive) punishment"; but not only they are not synonyms, but actually literal antonyms (a subject noticing the improving of "negative liberty" in relation to a need, versus a subject noticing an obstacle when pathing towards some nice expectancy).  The usual conflation happens because of tranferable learning with the words from different contexts. I know the work of Piaget and Montesorri well and taught the theories in Early Chilhood Development under grad psych courses. I dont think they are incorrect but there is more genetic influence on learning than we wsnt to admit.  I do know that all the Head Start Research shows a slight positive effect for up to two years three at most for children in Head Start. And I do know the demographic you mention.Some of the problems are the atitutudes toward education in the home. No books, never seeing a parent read a book, parents modeling other bahaviors like daytime TV , TV on junk shows all day and all night as background noise so children HAVE NO quiet place to read if they want to. And that is in the more pleasant environments...I wont mention the bad ones...we all know what goes on in the bad homes. THOSE poor kids have almost no chance of learning much or coming out healthy and happy in adulthood , who would?  However recent studies, twin studies in Australia with samples in the thousands of twins separated at birth show statisticslly that identical twins raised in very different homes, positive ones and negative ones,end up.having almost the very same outcomes! This means genetics plays a MUCH stronger role than environment. Those children were not usually placed in the WORST homes because agencies do try to screen for alcoholism, drug addiction, police records of violent homes etc...but these studies show a very high genetic component to outcomes.See the work of Pinker...he shows FMRIbraiin scans of the structures of brains active in learning tasks etc where both identical twins have the same anatomical activations like exact maps of each other so different environments have been conclusively SHOWN to NOT have changed neural pathways and structures and neurotransmitters in brains solving cognitive problems, etc etc so all the Head Start, Piaget, Montessori etc ie ENRICHMENT of learning has far less effect than we had hoped. Not to mention the decades of anecdotal and outcome research showing the same.  Perhaps you dont want to believe that, the education establishment certainly does not want to believe that, because it is an industry requiring ever mushrooming amounts of funds to provide these demonstration projects that turn into generally funded curricula...as I said, an industry and one that does not stand up to close statistical evaluative research regarding results. They say " well it isnt us its the home" but more and more research sadly shows this NOT to be true.   There is now  strong predictive results showing heritablity in IQ, all sorts of abilities, interests, mental illnesses ( my field of specialty as a clincical psychologist and professor training grad stdents as well as undergrads). NONE of us likes this, but for HONEST scientists and researchers more and more of the research is irrefutable.  We want SO MUCH to save people, to cure people, to.fix people, to help people learn better and more, to help people be more succesdful, happier, with less personal strife and suffering but there is no magic pill, education theory, or psychologicsl theory that does that. 5:40 Negative reinforcement is the removal of an adverse stimulus to increase a behavior. Positive/negative indicate whether a stimulus was added or removed. Reinforcement/punishment indicate whether the behavior will increase or decrease (or whether the outcome is positive or negative). Punishment in layman's terms refers to Positive punishment- the addition of an adverse stimulus. This is a common mistake people make. Positive reinforcement: giving a dog a treat for sitting. Negative reinforcement: letting a dog out of its carrier for being quiet (being removed from adverse stimulus). Positive punishment: slapping a dog on the nose for barking. Negative punishment: taking a dogs toy away because the dog is destroying it. DISCLAIMER: I am NOT a die hard behaviorist and understand Professor Sapolsky is way smarter than me and I agree with him, I am simply correcting a simple mistake

I've seen an even more impressive demonstration of numeracy in chimps.  Chimps can be trained to associate numeral figures with values in terms of a number of treats.  They come to associate for example,  the numeral "4" with four treats, and recognise that it's bigger than "3".   Eventually you get to where you have two chimps that can see each other but not interact. One chimp has to choose from between two numerals, and the number of treats they choose is given to the other chimp. The choosing chimp soon learns to always pick the lower value numeral so that the other chimp gets fewer treats than it does.   The fun part is, if you replace abstract numerals with actual piles of treats, the choosing chimp always selects the greater pile (which then goes to the other chimp). They can deal in abstract numbers but can't get over the instinct to grab the bigger pile of food. I've seen footage of this, and the chimps face-palm when they realise what they have done, so evidently they still know the rules, but can't stop themselves.

I enjoy these classes too and his books are fabulous!! That said it is incredibly annoying to hear him bash Skinner and then go on to explain basic reinforcement concepts incorrectly. Within the first 10 minutes he equated negative reinforcement with punishment, which reveals a complete misunderstanding of the terms, because essentially these are opposites. He seems to be using positive and negative in the good/bad sense, when in reality Skinner intended positive and negative to mean something very specific: the addition or subtraction of a stimulus that influences the future probability of a particular behavior. This includes positive reinforcement (stimulus added and rate of behavior increases), negative reinforcement (stimulus removed and behavior increases), positive punishment (stimulus added which decreases behavior), and negative punishment (stimulus removed which decreases behavior). I'm disappointed that he messed this up, but I'm still a huge fan.

Generally no, for four reasons:   - Except for pretty rare situations, what you learn doesn't change your genes to preserve that information. That's Lamarckian evolution and it's not how things generally work. What you learn can create an outcome that in turn has heritable consequences, but that's not the same thing, and it's not going to preserve the thing you learned - it might just reinforce it. And that kind of repetition across generations would generally not function as a fixed action pattern.  For example, five immigrants move to a new country. One of them learns the local language, four don't. The one who learns the language ends up with a better job and their kids are bigger, stronger and have less prenatal stress. This can become heritable (these kids might in turn be more likely to have bigger, stronger kids with less prenatal stress), but it doesn't mean the kids or their kids or their kids come out speaking a language. They might be more likely to learn it because of the factors that were passed down - but that's not a fixed action pattern and it will never become "hard-wired."  - If it's selected for gradualistically, then it's not "learned."  It's just at some point at random a gull started turning their shells over because of some biological drive, and then that gull out-reproduced the others. Yeah it might look like the gull learned how to do it, but that's not what's happening.  If there's a behavioral component, it might involve a behavior that brought the organism into a new environment or exposed them to some new pressure that prompted the trait to outcompete. Maybe.  - If you remember the bit about epigenetics and transcription factors, the way our heritable information becomes part of our physical body and behavior involves a lot of complex "if-then" statements, where a small change in a factor, or in the environment, or in the part of our genetic code that is not expressed into amino acids and proteins can change a whole bunch of things at once. And so the gull might have been doing some unrelated thing that involved speckles or wanting to turn things over, it might have been a spandrel from some other characteristic, and with a tweak to the right transcription factor suddenly the gull is turning over their eggs. The fixed action pattern does not have to have originated from something that had a similar purpose.  - Fixed action patterns are not so precise as to be the same as advantageous behaviors. The environment or situation can change the outcome of the fixed action pattern, or what it would look like to a human observer - the action pattern is fixed, but what it means or what it accomplishes are not fixed. The narrative of what the animal is doing and why is always a cognitive shortcut.
